title: Authors and Citation

title: Authors and Citation
text: Eaton B, Davidson S, Coia V, MacKenzie L (2024). gbem: Physical model calculate riverbank erosion volume. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://stochagbem.github.io/gbem/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {gbem: Physical model to calculate riverbank erosion volume},   author = {Brett Eaton and Sarah Davidson and Vincenzo Coia and Lucy MacKenzie},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://stochagbem.github.io/gbem/}, }

what: Physical model to calculate riverbank erosion volume
title: Physical model to calculate riverbank erosion volume
text: goal gbem calculate erosion volumes expected river’s cross section, given flow magnitude duration. WARNING: package active development intended used yet.

title: Physical model to calculate riverbank erosion volume
text: gbem CRAN, can install GitHub running following command R: doesn’t work, may install remotes package command install.packages("remotes").

title: Physical model to calculate riverbank erosion volume
Physical model to calculate riverbank erosion volume
text: Make hydrograph scratch:  , data frame; time, also specify time multiplier:  canned hydrographs snowmelt-related rainfall-related events, :   can easily discretize hydrograph ’d like manual calculations:
code: hg <- hydrograph(   2 ~ 0, 3 ~ 1, 5 ~ 2, 3 ~ 5, 2 ~ 10 ) plot(hg) data.frame(times = c(0, 1 / 3, 1), flow = c(100, 500, 200)) |>    as_hydrograph(times_from = times, flows_from = flow, unit = 24) |>    plot() hydrograph_rain(peak = 200, baseflow = 50) |>    plot() hydrograph_snow(peak = 200, baseflow = 50) |>    plot() discretize_hydrograph(hg, 10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 2 #>     time  flow #>    <dbl> <dbl> #>  1  0     2    #>  2  1.11  3.22 #>  3  2.22  4.85 #>  4  3.33  4.11 #>  5  4.44  3.37 #>  6  5.56  2.89 #>  7  6.67  2.67 #>  8  7.78  2.44 #>  9  8.89  2.22 #> 10 10     2

title: Physical model to calculate riverbank erosion volume
text: Make channel cross section:
code: cs <- cross_section(width = 3, grad = 0.01, d50 = 0.1, d84 = 0.5, roughness = 0.01) cs #> Channel with width 3

title: Physical model to calculate riverbank erosion volume
text: Execute algorithm constant flow running gbem(). returns gbem object containing information channel changes. Run erode() execute changes get new cross section: can also iterate GBEM across hydrograph.
code: g1 <- gbem(100, t = 1, cross_section = cs) erode(g1) #> Channel with width 299.403582260773 g2 <- gbem2(hg, cross_section = cs, niter = 100) erode(g2) #> Channel with width 23.4198648991414

what: Coerce an object to an event hydrograph — as_hydrograph
title: Coerce an object to an event hydrograph — as_hydrograph
text: Turn object event hydrograph.

title: Coerce an object to an event hydrograph — as_hydrograph
code: as_hydrograph(x, ...)  # S3 method for data.frame as_hydrograph(x, ..., times_from, flows_from, unit = 1)

title: Coerce an object to an event hydrograph — as_hydrograph
text: x data frame coerce hydrograph. ... Used extensions specific coercion methods. times_from Column name containing timings hydrograph change points, including terminus times. Unquoted. flows_from Column name containing discharge values corresponding timings times_from column. Unquoted. unit Conversion factor time values; single numeric. Useful , example, timing specified proportion total event time.

title: Coerce an object to an event hydrograph — as_hydrograph
text: event hydrograph, hydrograph(), made linearly interpolated discharge-timing pairs.

title: Coerce an object to an event hydrograph — as_hydrograph
code: df <- data.frame(when = 0:3, flows = c(2, 5, 4, 2)) h <- as_hydrograph(df, times_from = when, flows_from = flows) plot(h)

what: Create a new channel cross section — cross_section
title: Create a new channel cross section — cross_section
text: Create channel cross section specifying properties.

title: Create a new channel cross section — cross_section
code: cross_section(width, grad, d50, d84, roughness, rootdepth = 0)

title: Create a new channel cross section — cross_section
text: width Channel width meters; single positive numeric. grad Energy gradient stream channel; single positive numeric. d50, d84 Grain size distribution's 50th 84th quantiles millimeters; single positive numerics. roughness Manning's roughness; positive single numeric. rootdepth Effective rooting depth vegetation; single non-negative numeric.

title: Create a new channel cross section — cross_section
text: "cross_section" object.

title: Create a new channel cross section — cross_section
text: Examples effective rooting depth vegetation, rootdepth, : grassy banks, trees / shrubs: rootdepth = 0.35. 1 5% tree / shrub cover: rootdepth = 0.50. 5 50% tree / shrub cover: rootdepth = 0.90. 50% tree / shrub cover: rootdepth = 1.10.

title: Create a new channel cross section — cross_section
text: Width assumed constant function depth.

title: Create a new channel cross section — cross_section
code: cross_section(3, grad = 0.01, d50 = 0.1, d84 = 0.5, roughness = 0.01) #> Channel with width 3

what: Snowmelt and Rainfall-Related Event Hydrographs — hydrograph_snow
title: Snowmelt and Rainfall-Related Event Hydrographs — hydrograph_snow
text: Constructs event hydrographs characteristic rainfall snowmelt-related event.

title: Snowmelt and Rainfall-Related Event Hydrographs — hydrograph_snow
code: hydrograph_snow(peak, baseflow, duration = 3 * 24)  hydrograph_rain(peak, baseflow, duration = 9 * 24)

title: Snowmelt and Rainfall-Related Event Hydrographs — hydrograph_snow
text: peak, baseflow Peak baseflow discharges; single numerics. duration Length event. Defaults 3 days rainfall-related events, 9 days snowmelt-related events (hours).

title: Snowmelt and Rainfall-Related Event Hydrographs — hydrograph_snow
text: Rainfall-related event hydrographs triangular, rising baseflow peak 1/3 duration, followed recession baseflow. Snowmelt-related event hydrographs like rainfall hydrographs, remain peak discharge half event duration.

title: Snowmelt and Rainfall-Related Event Hydrographs — hydrograph_snow

title: Main GBEM Workhorse — gbem
text: Run gravel-bed river bank erosion model determine channel changes.

title: Main GBEM Workhorse — gbem
Main GBEM Workhorse — gbem
text: Q Discharge carried stream t Time Q acts stream channel (hrs) cross_section "cross_section" object.

title: Main GBEM Workhorse — gbem
text: list following components: dw_pred: predicted widening. dw_const: change width constrained transport capacity, v_b: transport capacity * time. Volume transport can moved river. cross_section: original cross section.

title: Main GBEM Workhorse — gbem
code: cs <- cross_section(5, grad = 0.01, d50 = 0.5, d84 = 0.5, roughness = 0.02) gbem(100, 1, cs) #> $dw_pred #> [1] 868069 #>  #> $dw_const #> [1] 176.3827 #>  #> $v_b #> [1] 101.8346 #>  #> $cross_section #> Channel with width 5

what:
Uses gbem to estimate the channel change during a flood hydrograph
with Q values for every hour of the floods — gbem2
title:
Uses gbem to estimate the channel change during a flood hydrograph
with Q values for every hour of the floods — gbem2
text: Uses gbem estimate channel change flood hydrograph Q values every hour floods

title:
Uses gbem to estimate the channel change during a flood hydrograph
with Q values for every hour of the floods — gbem2

Uses gbem to estimate the channel change during a flood hydrograph
with Q values for every hour of the floods — gbem2
text: hydrograph Event hydrograph carried stream, time units hours. cross_section Cross section stream. niter Number iterations run algorithm .

title:
Uses gbem to estimate the channel change during a flood hydrograph
with Q values for every hour of the floods — gbem2
text: discretized event hydrograph erosion widths volumes time step.

title:
Uses gbem to estimate the channel change during a flood hydrograph
with Q values for every hour of the floods — gbem2
code: hg <- hydrograph_snow(5, 2) cs <- cross_section(3, grad = 0.01, d50 = 0.1, d84 = 0.5, roughness = 0.01) g <- gbem2(hg, cs) erode(g) #> Channel with width 67.9528711767487

title: Construct an event hydrograph — hydrograph
text: Construct event hydrograph linearly connecting pairs discharge timing.

title: Construct an event hydrograph — hydrograph
Construct an event hydrograph — hydrograph
text: ... Pairs discharges timing separated ~. unit Conversion factor time values; single numeric. Useful , example, timing specified proportion total event time. env Environment search bindings, case discharge-timing pairs specified symbolically.

title: Construct an event hydrograph — hydrograph
text: data frame two columns: time event, discharge time. Returns tibble tibble package installed.

title: Construct an event hydrograph — hydrograph
code: # Hydrograph over 10 units of time: my_hydrograph <- hydrograph(2 ~ 0, 5 ~ 1 / 3, 2 ~ 1, unit = 10) plot(my_hydrograph, n = 1000)   # Hydrograph spanning 24 hours: my_hydrograph <- hydrograph(3 ~ 0, 5 ~ 10, 4.8 ~ 15, 3 ~ 24) plot(my_hydrograph, n = 1000)

title: Run stochasim using hydrographs and two flood generating mechanisms — stochasim_dual
text: floods_snow output make_floods floods_rain output make_floods Q_base Mean annual flow n Manning's n value main channel d84 84th percentile surface grain size distribution (mm) d50 50th percentile grain size distribution (mm) width_0 Water surface width beginning time interval T slope Energy gradient stream channel H Effective rooting depth vegetation
